expanded_description: This section introduces speed and velocity, two related but distinct concepts for describing how fast an object is moving. Speed is a scalar quantity that tells how fast an object is moving, while velocity is a vector that includes both speed and direction.

core_concept.principle: Speed tells how fast an object is moving, regardless of direction. Velocity tells both how fast and in what direction an object is moving. This distinction is crucial because velocity, as a vector, can be positive or negative and affects how we combine motions.
core_concept.explanation: A car traveling at 60 km/h has a speed of 60 km/h. Its velocity could be 60 km/h east, 60 km/h north, or 60 km/h in any direction. The direction matters when considering changes in motion or when adding velocities from different reference frames.

image.alt: Diagram comparing speed (speedometer reading) with velocity (speedometer plus compass direction)
image.caption: Speed is a scalar (magnitude only); velocity is a vector (magnitude and direction)

sections.introduction: Speed is a measure of how fast an object is moving. It tells us the rate at which distance is covered, without any information about direction.

key_concept.definition: Speed is the rate at which an object covers distance. It is a scalar quantity, calculated as distance traveled divided by time taken.
key_concept.context: Speed is what a speedometer in a car measures. It tells you how fast you're going, but not where you're headed. A car can have constant speed while turning, because speed doesn't care about direction.

principles.statement: Average speed is the total distance traveled divided by the total time taken: $v_{avg} = \frac{d}{\Delta t}$.
principles.application: Use this when you know the total path length and total time, regardless of what happened in between.
principles.example: If you drive 150 km in 3 hours, your average speed is $150 \text{ km} / 3 \text{ h} = 50 \text{ km/h}$.
principles.analogy: Like your overall pace on a hike - total miles divided by total hours, ignoring hills and rests.

principles.statement: Instantaneous speed is the speed at a specific instant in time. It's what a speedometer shows at any given moment.
principles.application: While average speed considers the whole trip, instantaneous speed can vary from moment to moment.
principles.example: During a 3-hour trip with average speed 50 km/h, you might have instantaneous speeds of 0 km/h at stoplights and 80 km/h on the highway.

principles.statement: As a scalar, speed has no direction and is always positive or zero.
principles.application: When reporting speed, you never use negative signs. Negative speed is meaningless.
principles.example: A car moving backward still has positive speed - its speedometer doesn't show negative numbers.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Average Speed
worked_examples.problem: A runner completes a 400 m lap in 50 seconds, then runs another 400 m lap in 60 seconds. What is the runner's average speed for the entire 800 m run?

step_by_step.explanation: Total distance = $400 \text{ m} + 400 \text{ m} = 800 \text{ m}$
Total time = $50 \text{ s} + 60 \text{ s} = 110 \text{ s}$
$v_{avg} = \frac{800 \text{ m}}{110 \text{ s}} = 7.27 \text{ m/s}$

worked_examples.concept_applied: Average speed uses total distance and total time, not the average of the two speeds.

sections.introduction: Velocity is a vector quantity that includes both speed and direction. It describes not only how fast an object is moving, but also where it's going.

key_concept.definition: Velocity is the rate of change of position. It is a vector quantity, calculated as displacement divided by time interval.
key_concept.context: Velocity matters when direction is important - for predicting where something will be, for understanding changes in motion, or when adding motions from different reference frames.

principles.statement: Average velocity is displacement divided by time interval: $\vec{v}_{avg} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{x_f - x_i}{t_f - t_i}$.
principles.application: Use this when you know the change in position (displacement) and the time taken. The sign tells direction.
principles.example: If you move from $x_i = 10 \text{ m}$ to $x_f = 30 \text{ m}$ in $5 \text{ s}$, your average velocity is $(30-10)/5 = +4 \text{ m/s}$ (positive direction).

principles.statement: Instantaneous velocity is the velocity at a specific instant. It tells both how fast and in what direction the object is moving at that moment.
principles.application: Like instantaneous speed but with direction included. A car's velocity changes when it turns, even if speed stays constant.
principles.example: A car going around a curve at constant 60 km/h has changing velocity because its direction changes continuously.

principles.statement: As a vector, velocity can be positive or negative depending on direction relative to your chosen sign convention.
principles.application: A negative velocity means motion in the negative direction, not necessarily slowing down.
principles.example: With east as positive, a car traveling west at 20 m/s has velocity $v = -20 \text{ m/s}$.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Average Velocity
worked_examples.problem: An object starts at $x = 5 \text{ m}$, moves to $x = 25 \text{ m}$ in $4 \text{ s}$, then immediately back to $x = 10 \text{ m}$ in another $3 \text{ s}$. Find the average velocity for the entire trip.

step_by_step.explanation:
Initial position: $x_i = 5 \text{ m}$
Final position: $x_f = 10 \text{ m}$
$\Delta x = 10 - 5 = +5 \text{ m}$
Total time = $4 \text{ s} + 3 \text{ s} = 7 \text{ s}$
$\vec{v}_{avg} = \frac{+5 \text{ m}}{7 \text{ s}} = +0.71 \text{ m/s}$

worked_examples.concept_applied: Average velocity uses displacement (final minus initial position), not total distance traveled.

worked_examples.title: Velocity Sign Interpretation
worked_examples.problem: A ball is thrown upward. At the top of its path, its velocity is zero. On the way up, velocity is positive; on the way down, velocity is negative. Explain why, using up as positive.

step_by_step.explanation: Up is positive, down is negative.
The ball is moving upward (positive direction), so velocity is positive.
The ball is momentarily at rest, so velocity is zero.
The ball is moving downward (negative direction), so velocity is negative.

worked_examples.final_answer: Velocity sign indicates direction: positive for up, negative for down, zero at the instant of direction change.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Velocity sign follows the chosen sign convention and changes when direction changes.

sections.introduction: Understanding the difference between average and instantaneous quantities is essential for correctly interpreting motion. Average gives the overall picture; instantaneous tells what's happening at a specific moment.

key_concept.definition: Average velocity (or speed) considers the entire motion over a time interval. Instantaneous velocity (or speed) is the value at a single instant.
key_concept.context: A car trip might have an average speed of 60 km/h, but instantaneous speeds vary from 0 to 100 km/h. Both are useful for different purposes.

classifications.value: Overall rate over a time interval
characteristics: Gives one number for the whole trip
classifications.behavior: Average velocity depends only on start and end points, not on path. Average speed depends on total path length. Both smooth out any variations during the trip.

examples.explanation: Round trip: displacement = 0, so average velocity = 0 regardless of speed.
Round trip: distance > 0, so average speed > 0.

characteristics: Can change from moment to moment
Limit of average as time interval approaches zero
classifications.behavior: Instantaneous velocity tells you exactly how fast and in what direction the object is moving right now. It's the slope of the position-time graph at that instant.

examples.explanation: Cruise control: instantaneous speed equals average speed at all times.
City driving: instantaneous speed varies, average speed is lower than maximum.

worked_examples.title: Average vs. Instantaneous
worked_examples.problem: A car travels at 80 km/h for 1 hour, then stops for 30 minutes, then travels at 60 km/h for 2 hours. Find (a) average speed, (b) average velocity if all motion is in the same direction.

step_by_step.explanation:
First segment: $d_1 = 80 \text{ km/h} \times 1 \text{ h} = 80 \text{ km}$
Second: $d_2 = 0 \text{ km}$ (stopped)
Third: $d_3 = 60 \text{ km/h} \times 2 \text{ h} = 120 \text{ km}$

Total distance = $80 + 0 + 120 = 200 \text{ km}$
Displacement = $200 \text{ km}$ (same direction)
Total time = $1 + 0.5 + 2 = 3.5 \text{ hours}$
$v_{avg\ speed} = 200 \text{ km} / 3.5 \text{ h} = 57.1 \text{ km/h}$
$\vec{v}_{avg} = 200 \text{ km} / 3.5 \text{ h} = 57.1 \text{ km/h}$ in the direction of motion
Instantaneous speeds varied: 80 km/h, 0 km/h, 60 km/h. Average smooths these out.

worked_examples.final_answer: Average speed = $57.1 \text{ km/h}$, Average velocity = $57.1 \text{ km/h}$ in direction of motion
worked_examples.concept_applied: When direction doesn't change, average speed magnitude equals average velocity magnitude. Both differ from instantaneous values.

image.alt: Graph showing position vs. time with secant line (average velocity) and tangent line (instantaneous velocity)
image.caption: Average velocity is the slope between two points; instantaneous velocity is the slope at a single point

sections.introduction: Understanding the distinction between speed and velocity is essential for correct problem-solving in kinematics.

characteristics: Speed is scalar; velocity is vector
Speed has no sign; velocity can be positive/negative
Speed uses distance; velocity uses displacement
classifications.behavior: These differences matter because: (1) velocity can change even when speed is constant (direction change), (2) adding velocities requires vector addition, (3) average velocity can be zero while average speed is positive.

examples.explanation: Object moving in circle at constant speed: speed constant, velocity constantly changing (direction changes).
Car going backward: speed positive, velocity negative.

principles.statement: Velocity tells you which way the object is moving; speed does not.
principles.application: Use velocity when direction matters for predicting future position or for vector addition.
principles.example: Two cars with same speed but opposite directions have different velocities and will end up in different places.

principles.statement: For an object moving in one direction, speed is the absolute value of velocity.
principles.application: If velocity is $v$, speed is $|v|$. This relationship breaks down if direction changes within the time interval.
principles.example: Velocity of $-15 \text{ m/s}$ gives speed of $15 \text{ m/s}$.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Speed and Velocity
worked_examples.problem: Identify each as speed or velocity: (a) 65 mph, (b) 30 m/s north, (c) -12 km/h, (d) 100 km/h on a speedometer.

step_by_step.explanation: (a) 65 mph: no direction → speed
(b) 30 m/s north: has direction → velocity
(c) -12 km/h: negative sign indicates direction (opposite to positive) → velocity
(d) 100 km/h on speedometer: speedometers show magnitude only → speed

worked_examples.concept_applied: Presence of direction (words or signs) indicates velocity; magnitude only indicates speed.

sections.introduction: Recognizing common errors helps students correctly apply speed and velocity concepts.

classifications.value: Using terms interchangeably when they have different meanings
characteristics: Saying velocity when only speed is known
classifications.behavior: This leads to incorrect calculations when direction matters, such as in collision problems or relative motion.

examples.explanation: Two cars approach each other at 60 km/h each. Student says relative speed is 60 km/h (should be 120 km/h because velocities are opposite).
One velocity = +60 km/h, other = -60 km/h, relative velocity = 120 km/h.

classifications.type: Using Distance Instead of Displacement for Velocity
classifications.value: Calculating average velocity using total distance instead of displacement
characteristics: Not considering start and end points
classifications.behavior: This error gives average speed, not average velocity. In round trips, it gives nonzero when velocity should be zero.

examples.explanation: Run 100 m north, then 100 m south in 40 s. Student calculates velocity = 200/40 = 5 m/s.

classifications.value: Taking arithmetic mean of speeds when times are different
characteristics: Adding speeds and dividing by number of segments
Ignoring time spent at each speed
classifications.behavior: Average speed is weighted by time, not simply the average of speeds. Equal distances at different speeds require harmonic mean, not arithmetic mean.

examples.explanation: Travel 100 km at 50 km/h and 100 km at 100 km/h. Student says average speed = (50+100)/2 = 75 km/h.
Time first half = 2 h, time second half = 1 h, total = 3 h, distance = 200 km, average speed = 200/3 = 66.7 km/h.

image.caption: Common errors include confusing speed/velocity and incorrect averaging

summary: Speed and velocity are related but distinct concepts in kinematics. Speed is a scalar quantity that measures how fast an object is moving - the rate at which distance is covered. Average speed is total distance divided by total time. Instantaneous speed is what a speedometer shows at a given moment. Velocity is a vector quantity that includes both speed and direction - the rate of change of position. Average velocity is displacement divided by time interval; instantaneous velocity is the velocity at a specific instant. Key differences: velocity can be positive or negative based on direction; speed is always positive. Velocity changes when direction changes, even if speed is constant. Average velocity can be zero while average speed is positive (round trip). Speed is the magnitude of instantaneous velocity when direction isn't changing. Understanding these distinctions is essential for correctly applying kinematics equations and solving motion problems, as many formulas require velocity (vector) while others use speed (scalar). Common mistakes include confusing the terms, using distance instead of displacement for velocity calculations, and incorrectly averaging speeds without considering time spent at each speed.
